comment: This might be a dumb question. Apart from the scope of the inputs, how is ChatGPT different from text autocomplete? I asked ChatGPT 3.5 already. It said, "ChatGPT can be used for a variety of applications beyond just completing sentences," which misses the point: Both ChatGPT and text autocomplete predict what a human will answer next when asked. ChatGPT predicts what ideas come next and expresses those in a coherent way that makes sense to human users, just like text autocomplete predicts what words should come next. Beyond that, how are they different?

comment:
His explanation about the jobs reminds me of that southpark episode with the gnomes. He's just like "we're all gonna be rich!"

If you can code something in a couple hours that used to take 2-3 people a week, how are those other people getting wealthier? 

You can apply this to probably most fields where people are using computers to do mundane and monotonous tasks. Accountants, bank workers, tax preparers, assistants, next up is developers, animators, computer security firms, on and on. 

So when 1 person and chatgpt can get more work done than 20 humans in a day,   how is this making society more wealthy?  

Chatgpt better solve greed, because i dont think the people using it to be 1000% more productive are going take the extra money and give it away to the millions of people who cant keep up. 

This is disruptive as fuck, people trust those at the upper echelons of society to fairly distribute the wealth?

On the bright side i would expect a slow transition. If everyone started 'the adoption' now, there would be so much displacement that it would seriously affect the global economy. How many % of all jobs can be augmented or replaced with just this iteration of gpt?  

UBI is now on the horizon, for some reason i dont think that will make the masses wealthier.

comment:
How will AI overcome the obstacle of new knowledge or unknowns? We as humans test and run "simulations" through other species to push beyond borders and that's how we get new knowledge. AI can't do that without some physical body to perform those things. Like cancer or new viruses.

And Lex is getting swooped into this IDW wormhole with his naive view of his close friends anti establishment ideologies. It's sad to see the integrity crumble piece by piece but in the end, he is human too. Just goes to show his bias as well.

comment:
Great podcast, but I would argue Lex tend to be more prone to humanizing or antropomorphizing the AI that I would like. Time and time again Sam warns Lex against this. Other thing is Lex ask questions about things that are both misleading and about topics he doesn't even understand, for example Lex ask Sam if GPT-4 is counscious, Sam replies he doesn't believe it to be so, and asks the same question in reply so Lex, then Lex doesn't even have a definition or a wild guess about what is counsciousness, so why would you ask something that don't even understand at a basic level (let aside the fact that the topic of counciousness is very controversial as it is its definition). That kind of low quality of questions can very easily lead to wishful thinking, which is something I found Lex has with respect towards AI and technology in general in this and previos interviews.
Aside from that, I liked a lot of the answers and the tone of them Sam gave.

author: @valentijn1

comment:
Or as chat-GPT would put it: "Lex Friedman and Sam discuss various topics related to artificial intelligence.
The commenter points out that Lex tends to anthropomorphize or humanize AI, which means to ascribe human characteristics or emotions to non-human entities like AI. They feel that this can be problematic because it blurs the line between what AI is and what humans are. Additionally, the commenter mentions that Lex asks questions that are misleading or about topics he doesn't fully understand. They give an example of Lex asking about consciousness without fully understanding what it means. This can be problematic because it can lead to wishful thinking or unfounded beliefs about AI.

However, the commenter also mentions that they enjoyed the podcast and appreciated the answers and tone of Sam's responses

comment: I do hope there is some age restriction or catering of content in some way. I don't want an AI talking to my small child like they are a grown man. That could be very damaging. Most tech companies tend to create software and services with adults in mind. I really wish all these companies would care for children and families. The world isn't full of adults. It's 30% children.  I'm sure they have some smart people working on these things but I felt compelled to say something as I feel the current tech climate is quite dangerous in terms of the way it is warping our society. Of course it's on parents to be careful what their children have access to at the end of the day, but I worry nonetheless.

author: @nosachamos

comment: The Jurassic Park movie moment of our time.  It begs the question: even though we can do it, does it mean that we should?  AI will make the impact of social media seem like a ripple in a pond. I foresee devastating effects.  With respect to the US, academics at the grade and high school levels have declined year after year for decades.  Students are getting worse at reading, math, science, etc.  The ability to critically "think" about a problem, a statement, a news story, etc.,  is eroding to scary lows.  Now comes along a technology that can be trained by much more clever individuals to convincingly lead these same people who rely upon the internet for damn near everything, and they'll take it as the gospel truth.  We have over 30 million people in the US who believe Trump won the 2020 election in spite of volumes of evidence that say otherwise.  This technology along with deep fakes will be disastrous.  I predict in the future Altman will ask himself, "What the fuk did I do?"   An Oppenheimer moment.
